source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: Up-to-date growth results on $Z _ { \Gamma ^ { - 2 } \cdot 5 \mathrm { N b } }$ pressure tube material from the DIDO reactor at AERE Harwell are presented.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: The observed temperature dependence and magnitude of growth are significantly different from the representations in a recently published model for in-reactor deformation of pressure tubes.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: A preliminary estimate of the anisotropic creep component of the in-service deformation suggests that the creep anisotropy may be different from that in the model (derived from small specimen stress relaxation tests).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: KEY WORDS: $Z \Gamma { \cdot } 2 . 5 \Gamma \mathrm { b }$ , irradiation growth, temperature, neutron fluence, pressure tubes, elongation

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: The "design equations" representing the deformation behavior of pressure tubes during operation [1,2] attribute most of the observed elongation (4 to $5 \ \mathrm { m m }$ per year of operation at $8 0 \%$ capacity) to irradiation growth.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: The temperature dependence of growth built into the model is based on very limited data for cold-worked and stress-relieved Zircaloy-2 for temperatures below $5 5 0 \mathrm { K }$ [3] and shows the growth rate to increase very gradually with temperature.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: More recent studies have shown the temperature dependence of growth of zirconium alloys to be complicated above $5 5 0 ~ \mathrm { K }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: No input to the temperature dependence of growth in the model was made based on data for $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } â€“ 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ because none existed at that time.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: A further complication in the interpretation of elongation in terms of growth is that the absolute values of the growth rates measured from small specimens in an experiment in the DIDO reactor at Harwell are a factor of three to four lower than their representation in the model [7].

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: The irradiation growth results given below were obtained from an irradiation experiment in DIDO [68] in inert gas at a fast flux of about $6 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 7 } \mathrm { n / m ^ { 2 } / s }$ $( E > 1 \mathrm { M e V } )$ at temperatures of 553, 583, and $6 2 3 \pm 5 \bf { K }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: The irradiation growth results given below were obtained from an irradiation experiment in DIDO [68] in inert gas at a fast flux of about $6 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 7 } \mathrm { n / m ^ { 2 } / s }$ $( E > 1 \mathrm { M e V } )$ at temperatures of 553, 583, and $6 2 3 \pm 5 \bf { K }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: The reported fast fluences are based on the activation of ${ } ^ { s 4 } \mathrm { F e }$ EY to ${ ^ { 5 4 } } \mathbf { M } \mathbf { n }$ interpreted in terms of a fission flux spectrum.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: Results for five experimental materials are reported here [6-8]. Materials designated AR and D1 are standard pressure tube materials and R1 is produced by a new fabrication route developed for reduced in-service elongation.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: For materials R1 and D1, irradiation growth results are available for specimens irradiated at 553, 583, and $6 2 3 \mathrm { ~ \bf ~ K ~ }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: For materials R1 and D1, irradiation growth results are available for specimens irradiated at 553, 583, and $6 2 3 \mathrm { ~ \bf ~ K ~ }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk1
evidence_span: For materials R1 and D1, irradiation growth results are available for specimens irradiated at 553, 583, and $6 2 3 \mathrm { ~ \bf ~ K ~ }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk2
evidence_span: Figure 1 shows the behavior of standard pressure tube materials AR and D1. In the longitudinal direction there is an initial positive strain of 2-3Ã—10^-4, followed by a transient of low strain rate with a duration of about 3Ã—10^25 n/mÂ² (E > 1 MeV), and finally a positive linear rate of between 2.5 and 4Ã—10^-29 mÂ²/n (E > 1 MeV). In the transverse direction there is an initial negative strain of 2Ã—10^-4 followed almost immediately by a negative steady rate (-2.0Ã—10^-29 mÂ²/n, E > 1 MeV, for D1).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk2
evidence_span: The behavior of the R1 material (Fig. 2) is unique. It exhibits an initial positive strain in the longitudinal direction similar to that of standard material, followed by a negative steady rate of -2.4Ã—10^-29 mÂ²/n (E > 1 MeV).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk2
evidence_span: It exhibits an initial negative strain in the transverse direction similar to standard material, followed by a steady negative rate of -1.4Ã—10^-29 mÂ²/n (E > 1 MeV).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk2
evidence_span: The P4 material exhibited little transient strain, and the growth rate averaged 4.2Ã—10^-29 mÂ²/n (E > 1 MeV).

evidence_span: The B2 material exhibited little strain in the first irradiation period and a growth rate averaging 2.5Ã—10^-29 mÂ²/n (E > 1 MeV)

evidence_span: The D1 material exhibited progressively smaller initial strains at 583 and 623 than at 553 K in the longitudinal direction and the transient strain is negative (Fig. 4).

evidence_span: The D1 material exhibited progressively smaller initial strains at 583 and 623 than at 553 K in the longitudinal direction and the transient strain is negative (Fig. 4).

evidence_span: The rate after a fluence of 3.2Ã—10^25 n/mÂ² (E > 1 MeV) is lower at 583 than at 553 K, averaging about 1.4Ã—10^-29 versus 2.9Ã—10^-29 mÂ²/n (E > 1 MeV).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: An assessment of the creep anisotropy exhibited by pressure tubes can be made by subtracting the growth rate observed in each direction in standard pressure tube material in DIDO (Fig. 1) from typical elongation and diametral strain rates observed in pressure tubes in service.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: The result (Table 2) shows a much higher ratio of axial to transverse creep rate than that given by current models (i.e., 0.63 versus 0.1).
property_name: axial to transverse creep rate ratio

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: A preliminary study of the temperature dependence of the elongation rates of pressure tubes in Pickering 3 and 4 and in Bruce 2 [16] has shown elongation rate to increase with temperature with a sensitivity greater than that predicted by current design equations.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: Biaxial creep tests, as a function of stress, are required on specimens with a crystallographic texture similar to that of pressure tubing to verify this increased contribution of creep to the elongation of pressure tubes. Such tests are underway in the NRU reactor at Chalk River and in the OSIRIS reactor at Saclay.
specimen_state: specimens with a crystallographic texture similar to that of pressure tubing

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: The temperature dependence of the growth rate of $\mathbf { Z r { - } } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N b }$ pressure tube material observed in the DIDO reactor at Harwell is the reverse of that in Zircaloy-2; hence the representation in the current pressure tube deformation models appears to be incorrect.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: The irradiation growth rates in DIDO are much lower than the elongation rates in power reactor pressure tubes (per unit of fast neutron fluence) and the growth rates predicted by the current design equations.

conditions.fluence: per unit of fast neutron fluence

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: Measurements of the concentration of $\mathsf { \Omega } ^ { \mathsf { g 3 m } } \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ in specimens of tubes removed from Pickering 4 and Bruce 2 and in growth specimens from DIDO to estimate the relative fast neutron fluences do not resolve this discrepancy.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: Growth specimens machined from the pressure tubes which had experienced fast fluences of $7 . 0 { - } 7 . 5 ~ \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ $( E > 1 \mathrm { \ M e V } _ { , }$ exhibited growth rates in DIDO similar to those observed in specimens irradiated to a similar level from zero fluence in DIDO.
specimen_state: Growth specimens machined from the pressure tubes

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: A preliminary estimate of the anisotropic creep component of the in-service deformation suggests that the creep behavior is different from that in the design equations (derived from small specimen tests in NRU).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: This could result in a stronger temperature dependence of the elongation rate than that given by the current model.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: The splitting of $\left. c \ + \ a \right.$ dislocations during irradiation has been observed by M. Griffiths. It occurs by climb.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: The 1/3(1123) dislocations split to give $1 / 6 \langle 2 0 \overline { { 2 } } 3 \rangle + 1 / 6 \langle 0 2 \overline { { 2 } } 3 \rangle$ . The two partials are indeed separated by a stacking fault and would be sessile, eliminating their contribution, by slip, to the creep process.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: The creep would. in principle, be more anisotropic once the contribution of the $\langle c + a \rangle$ dislocations was eliminated.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: In our studies, upper bound and lower bound models give quite different results for the contribution of irradiation creep (with a stress exponent of one) to elongation of pressurized (closed end) tubes.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_017_chunk4
evidence_span: When the stress exponent is large there is little contribution of creep to elongation in either case.
